page.title: 01THE COLYTON AREA
page.content: Colyton is a small, ancient town in rural East Devon. Its population was 2422 in 1981. It lies on the Coly, a tributary of the River Axe, which flows into the sea about 3 miles to the south. Colyton was first settled in early Saxon times and the town has developed slowly, but continuously, since then. Its narrow winding streets, many of them with high walls on each side, and the larger open squares contain beautiful examples of many kinds of architecture. The Parish Church of St Andrew, with its unusual octagonal lantern tower, dominates the town. The Feoffees, established in the 16th century to buy back lands from Henry VIII, still meet in the Feoffees' Town Hall. The surrounding area depends heavily on dairy farming and is very attractive with its rolling hills and deep valleys.
